cluster.title: Hillary Clinton testifies before House Oversight Committee on Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

synthesis.narrative:
## State of the Story: Hillary Clinton's Epstein Deposition

### Key Facts Established

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton testified before the House Oversight Committee on Thursday, February 26, 2026, in a closed-door deposition regarding Jeffrey Epstein [1][2][3]. The hearing took place at the Chappaqua Performing Arts Center in New York, near the Clintons' home [2][3][7].

Clinton maintained she has no knowledge that would assist the investigation, stating in her opening remarks: "I do not recall ever encountering Mr. Epstein. I never flew on his plane or visited his island, homes or offices" [3][8]. She told lawmakers she "never met Jeffrey Epstein" and met Ghislaine Maxwell "only a few times" [1].

### Procedural Disruption

The deposition was temporarily paused after conservative influencer Benny Johnson posted photos of Clinton from inside the hearing room on social media, allegedly provided by Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) [2][3][5][8]. This violated House rules prohibiting photography during closed-door proceedings [3][5]. The hearing resumed after the interruption [3][8].

### Political Accusations

Clinton delivered sharp criticism of the Republican-led committee, accusing them of conducting "partisan political theatre" and a "fishing expedition" [5][8]. She alleged the hearing was designed "to distract attention from President Trump's actions and to cover them up" [1][2][4][5]. Clinton argued the committee should instead question Trump "under oath about the tens of thousands of times he shows up in the Epstein files" [5][8].

### Historical Significance

This marks the first time a former first couple has appeared before a congressional panel under subpoena [1]. Former President Bill Clinton is scheduled to testify Friday, which would be the first time a former president has testified before Congress in over 40 years [1][7].

### Committee Response

Committee Chairman James Comer (R-Ky.) stated that "no one's accusing the Clintons of any wrongdoing" and emphasized they would have "due process" [1][2]. Comer described the investigation as seeking to understand how Epstein "amassed his wealth" and money he raised for the Clinton Foundation [1]. He characterized the motion to bring in the Clintons as "bipartisan" [8].

### Areas of Agreement and Disagreement

All sources agree on the basic facts: Clinton testified she had no knowledge of Epstein's crimes, the hearing was temporarily disrupted by leaked photos, and she criticized the Republican-led investigation. Sources consistently report her denial of ever meeting Epstein and her accusation that the committee is protecting Trump.

The main disagreement centers on the legitimacy of the investigation itself, with Republicans framing it as necessary fact-finding [1][8] while Democrats and Clinton characterize it as partisan theater [5][8].

Deposition temporarily paused after Rep. Lauren Boebert allegedly leaked photos from closed-door hearing
Clinton accused Republican committee of conducting 'fishing expedition' to protect Trump
First time former first couple has testified before Congress under subpoena
Bill Clinton scheduled to testify Friday in historic appearance by former president

claims.text: Hillary Clinton testified that she has no new information about Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell
Hillary Clinton stated she does not recall ever encountering or meeting Jeffrey Epstein
Hillary Clinton said she never flew on Epstein's plane or visited his island, homes or offices
Hillary Clinton accused the Republican committee of engaging in partisan 'fishing expeditions' to distract from Trump's actions
The deposition was briefly paused after conservative influencer Benny Johnson posted photos from the closed-door proceedings
Rep. Lauren Boebert provided the photos to Benny Johnson
Committee Chair James Comer said no one is accusing the Clintons of wrongdoing at this moment
Bill Clinton is scheduled to testify on Friday
This will be the first time a former president has testified before a congressional panel in over 40 years
Hillary Clinton's name does not appear in the Justice Department's publicly released Epstein files
Hillary Clinton told the New York Times that she met Maxwell only a few times
Hillary Clinton did not invoke her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination
The Clintons were threatened with contempt of Congress charges if they did not appear
Trump shows up tens of thousands of times in the Epstein files
Trump has never been charged with any wrongdoing connected to Epstein and has denied any wrongdoing
The Clintons have repeatedly denied wrongdoing related to Epstein and have not been accused of any crimes in connection with him

frames.name: Partisan Political Theater
frames.description: Frames the hearing as a Republican-led distraction from Trump's connections to Epstein, emphasizing Clinton's accusations of a 'cover-up' and 'fishing expedition'
frames.emphasis: Clinton's criticism of GOP motives, accusations of protecting Trump, and characterization as partisan distraction

frames.name: Procedural Congressional Investigation
frames.description: Presents the hearing as a legitimate bipartisan congressional investigation with proper procedures and due process
frames.emphasis: Committee chair's statements about bipartisan support, due process, and legitimate investigative purpose

frames.name: Historical Precedent
frames.description: Emphasizes the unprecedented nature of a former first couple and former president testifying under subpoena
frames.emphasis: First time in 40+ years a former president has testified to Congress, historical significance of the moment

frames.name: Rules Violation Controversy
frames.description: Focuses on the procedural breach when Rep. Boebert allegedly shared photos from the closed-door hearing
frames.emphasis: Violation of House rules, temporary suspension of proceedings, Democratic condemnation of the breach

outlierPerspectives: Al Jazeera uniquely frames this as part of broader accountability efforts for those who may have 'shielded Epstein from justice' and provides extensive context about Epstein's victim count and 2008 plea deal
Breitbart emphasizes the Clintons' age (both 79) and includes a 'RELATED' link to Trump criticism, presenting a more conservative perspective on the proceedings
missingContext: Specific details about what evidence or documents the committee has that prompted the subpoenas
Clear explanation of what legal authority the House Oversight Committee has in this investigation
Details about the scope and timeline of the broader Epstein investigation
Information about other witnesses who have been called or may be called
Context about the relationship between this congressional investigation and ongoing DOJ investigations
Explanation of why the Clintons were specifically targeted when their names don't appear prominently in released Epstein files

predictions.basis: Historic nature as first former president to testify before Congress in 40+ years

predictions.text: Republicans will face criticism for procedural violations and leaked photos incident
predictions.basis: Clear violation of House rules regarding closed-door proceedings

predictions.text: Investigation will expand to examine Trump's connections to Epstein

predictions.text: Committee will find no criminal wrongdoing by the Clintons

predictions.text: Investigation will become campaign issue in 2026 midterms
predictions.basis: High-profile nature and partisan divide over investigation's legitimacy

deepAnalysis.historicalContext: This investigation occurs against the backdrop of Jeffrey Epstein's 2019 death in federal custody while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges, and Ghislaine Maxwell's 2021 conviction for similar crimes. The Epstein case has repeatedly intersected with high-profile political figures from both parties. Congressional investigations of former presidents are extremely rare - the last occurred over 40 years ago. The Clinton Foundation has faced previous Republican scrutiny during Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign and her tenure as Secretary of State. This represents the latest chapter in decades-long partisan battles between Republicans and the Clintons, dating back to the 1990s Whitewater investigation and Bill Clinton's impeachment.
implications: Sets precedent for congressional subpoena power over former presidents and first ladies
May establish new norms around investigating political figures' associations with convicted criminals
Could influence 2026 midterm elections by energizing both Republican and Democratic bases
Raises questions about House rules enforcement and consequences for procedural violations
May prompt calls for equal scrutiny of Trump's Epstein connections
Could impact public trust in congressional oversight if viewed as purely partisan
Demonstrates continued political relevance of the Clinton family despite being out of office
May influence how future administrations handle associations with controversial figures
